awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding how neuroscience is changing the relationship between the state and US veterans with war disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Mild Traumatic Brain Injury (mTBI) and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) are the signature injuries of the recent US wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Such injuries pose difficulties in transitioning to civilian life and long-term challenges for veterans and their families. Veterans with war-acquired disabilities constitute a population needing immediate and long-term social, vocational, and medical support. Knowledge of how veterans understand and use biomedical and neuroscientific research can enhance communication between scientists, clinicians, and veterans, and also promote improved scientific and health literacy on mTBI and PTSD. This project also aims to document veterans' unmet needs, while collaboratively identifying solutions among key stakeholders in veteran care. Finally, this study hopes to aid clinical and social understandings of the individual and deeply personal meanings attached to a diagnostic category as it moves between the bench of basic science research and the bedside of clinical practice. The results of this research will be shared with military and healthcare professionals, and among anthropologists and other social scientists interested in studies of war trauma, neuroscience, veteran health, and disability. The project also will provide for the training of an MD-PhD graduate student in anthropology.

Mobilized by the need to better care for returning veterans, the US Government, clinicians, scientists, and soldiers have increasingly turned to the neurosciences to provide insights into these war-acquired disabilities. Jennifer Baldwin, under the supervision of Dr. Jane Desmond of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, will explore the emergent meanings produced by neurscientific research, and the effect of this new knowledge on how veterans, clinicians, and researchers at Veteran Affairs (VA) hospitals understand the different types of traumas with which veterans are suffering. This project employs participant-observation, interview, and community health methodologies to evaluate: a) What role do evolving neuroscientific knowledge and technologies play in transforming understandings of PTSD and mTBI for clinicians, neuroscience researchers, and veterans? b) Are research developments in the neurosciences changing how veterans diagnosed with these conditions characterize themselves, their conditions, and their life goals? And if so, how? c) What do neuroscientific explanations of war-acquired brain/mind traumas allow and disavow with regards to veterans' own understandings of their experiences at war and upon homecoming? and d) How does the use of neuroscientific knowledge and techniques by VA clinical and research spaces influence the relationship between these veterans and the state? This research contributes to the study of medical and cultural anthropology by analyzing how recent neuroscientific research on PTSD and mTBI is transforming how the state cares for returning veterans, as well as clinical, social, and veterans' perspectives about the effects of violence, trauma, and war. This study thus contributes broader insight into the relationship between medical authority, state power, and new forms of citizenship that emerge and are negotiated in VA clinical spaces.

por.por_cntn:
Mild Traumatic Brain Injuries (mTBI) and Post-traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) constitute the signature injuries of the recent US wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. Many veterans with these conditions face difficulties in transitioning to civilian life and longer-term challenges requiring medical, vocational, and social support. During these wars, the US Government, clinicians, scientists, and veterans increasingly turned to the neurosciences to provide insights into these war-acquired disabilities while also mobilizing existing Veteran Affairs (VA) clinical staff, clinics, and resources to tackle the medical and social needs of returning US veterans. This project examined clinical, veteran, and scientific understandings of mTBI and PTSD at a time when the US government sought new neuroscientific understandings of PTSD and TBI, as well as ways to surveil and manage the occurrence of these war traumas in US soldiers and veterans. This project examined these relationships to yield the following outcomes: (1) Described how neuroscientific understandings influenced the meanings of PTSD and mTBI for VA clinicians and OIF/OEF veterans; (2) Documented how research developments in the neurosciences changed how veterans diagnosed with mTBI or PTSD characterized their injuries and their experiences at war and upon homecoming. Identified other influences on how veterans understood mTBI and PTSD; (3) Critically assessed the adequacy of contemporary clinical and research models of PTSD and mTBI in describing veterans' experiences with these conditions at war and upon returning home; and (4) Analyzed what the clinical meanings, practices, and models of care for mTBI and PTSD applied within VA hospitals revealed about the US government's strategies to manage the effects of war for OEF/OIF veterans.

Intellectual Merit:

Through analysis of clinical, scientific, and social discourses and practices regarding PTSD and mTBI, this study demonstrated the broader political and social desires of the US government and body politic in managing these traumatic effects of war. This study documented the ways in which social understandings of veterans' experiences at war were strongly influenced by biomedical and neuroscientific models of war trauma and injuries. At a time when government-sponsored research initiatives demonstrated a predominance and privileging of neuroscientific approaches to PTSD and mTBI, this project ethnographically documented the limited applicability and use of these neuroscientific models in diagnosing and treating PTSD and mTBI in VA clinical spaces.

This project also contributed insight into how bureaucratic practices of the state impacted everyday medical practices including clinical assessments, diagnosis, and therapy. This study suggested that the state through its mandate and oversight of everyday bureaucratic practices contributed to variability in how medical diagnosis was made in VA clinical spaces. Historians of science and biomedicine have previously documented how diagnosis as both an object and practice of western biomedical tradition(s) changes over time. Social scientists have also described inter-clinician variability in diagnosis that reflects differences in such things as clinical training and clinician preferences for more aggressive versus conservative diagnostic inclusion criteria. In both bodies of scholarship, the assumed drivers of change in diagnostic practices include changing professional and public consensus, as well as changes in the nature and interpretation of scientific evidence. Yet, this study described the way in which state practices and bureaucratic policies organized and facilitated a range of clinical practices that shaped clinical diagnosis, management, and outcomes for the two signature injuries of the US wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. By examining the clinical practices of VA clinicians for PTSD and mTBI, this study demonstrated how everyday clinical practices for a given medical diagnosis integrate and negotiate a heterogeneous range of social, political, bureaucratic, and epistemological factors. Moreover, this project also revealed some of the sources and consequences of this heterogeneity for patient populations, professional cultures, and public knowledge. These findings may be of interest to medical anthropologists and scholars of the social study of science and technology. Methodologically, this research also contributed information on working with electronic medical records as a source of archival material regarding medical diagnostic practices, health professional cultures, and processes of clinical decision making. This would be of interest to researchers in the health sciences, as well as medical humanities. 

Broader Impact:

This project contributed to greater scientific and clinical understanding of veterans' perspectives and unmet needs regarding their experiences with mTBI and PTSD, and provided training for an MD-PhD graduate student in anthropology.
